title: Premier League of Bosnia and Herzegovina
text:
The M:tel Premier League of Bosnia and Herzegovina (), also known as Liga 12, is the top tier <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20football%20league%20system">league</a> in <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, and is operated by the <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Football Association of Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>. As the country's most prestigious level of football competition, the league changed format in the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">2016–17 season</a> and is contested by 12 clubs with the last two teams relegated at the end of every season.
The League is, as of the 2021–22 season, represented by four clubs in European competition. The winner of the Premier League starts from the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> first qualifying round. The winner of the <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20Football%20Cup">Bosnia and Herzegovina Football Cup</a> as well as the runner up and third placed team on the table starts from the first qualifying round of the <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Europa League</a>. From the 2021–22 season, the runner up and third placed team on the table will start from the first qualifying round of the newly established <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20Conference%20League">UEFA Europa Conference League</a>.
At the end of the season, the bottom two teams are relegated while winners of the <a href="First%20League%20of%20the%20Federation%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">First League of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> and the <a href="First%20League%20of%20the%20Republika%20Srpska">First League of the Republika Srpska</a> are promoted to the Premier League of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
History.
War period 1992–1996.
After <a href="breakup%20of%20Yugoslavia">breakup of Yugoslavia</a>, and following proclamation of independence in late winter 1992, <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> clubs left the <a href="Yugoslav%20First%20League">Yugoslav First League</a>, which ceased to exist after the 1991-92 season. Already in April the same year <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">N/FSBiH</a> applied for membership with FIFA and UEFA. Meanwhile, due to the outbreak of <a href="Bosnian%20War">Bosnian War</a> in April 1992 no games were played in the 1992–93 season. In late 1993 some parts of the country re-launched football competitions with reduced scope. But just as the country was divided along ethnic lines, so was football.
In 1993 <a href="Croats%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnian Croats</a> launched the <a href="Football%20Federation%20of%20Herzeg%20Bosnia">Football Federation of Herzeg Bosnia</a> and its <a href="First%20League%20of%20Herzeg-Bosnia">First League of Herzeg-Bosnia</a>, in which only Croatian clubs competed on parochial scale within the limits of <a href="West%20Herzegovina">West Herzegovina</a> and few other enclaves. In the same year <a href="Serbs%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnian Serbs</a> also organized their own <a href="First%20League%20of%20the%20Republika%20Srpska">First League of the Republika Srpska</a>, on a territory held by Republika Srpska regime at the time.
Only football on a territory under the control of then <a href="Republic%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> institutions and auspices of N/FSBiH, at the time consequently with <a href="Bosniaks">Bosniak</a> majority, apart from a brief competition for the season <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20First%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">1994–95</a> (won by <a href="NK%20%C4%8Celik%20Zenica">Čelik Zenica</a>), came to a standstill. 
Competition under auspices of N/FSBiH did not resume until <a href="1995%E2%80%9396%20First%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">1995–96</a> season when the <a href="First%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">First League of Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> was launched.
Post-war period 1996–2000.
These three separate football leagues were operating in Bosnia and Herzegovina until 1998, and 2000. Since FIFA and UEFA showed support only for the association operating under patronage of the official and internationally recognized state institutions, during the war and prior to "<a href="Dayton%20Agreement">Dayton Peace Agreement</a>" as well as after its signage, they endorsed unification of all three organizations as N/FSBiH. This also came as a consequence of FIFA decision to recognize N/FSBiH already in July 1996, while in the same year UEFA admitted N/FSBiH as an adjacent member until 1998 when they recognized its full membership. This meant that only N/FSBiH clubs and its <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20national%20football%20team">national team</a> could compete at the international and official level.
Final unification has been preceded by several stages. At first was created a playoff where clubs were playing for the champion under N/FSBiH auspices. Idea was that playoff under unified N/FSBiH auspices should bring together clubs competing under three separate organizations for the first time but was rejected by Serb association, leaving clubs from Croat football association and N/FSBiH participating playoff for the seasons <a href="1997%E2%80%9398%20First%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">1997–98</a> and <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20First%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">1999–00</a>, while <a href="1998%E2%80%9399%20First%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">1998–99</a> playoff was canceled due to Croat's association hesitation on the decision on which stadiums games should be played. Next season playoff was resumed for the last time prior to full and final agreement on unified N/FSBiH and its competition, Premier League BiH "(Premijer Liga)", in the fall 2000.
Premier League creation 2000–01.
Full and final agreement on unified N/FSBiH and its competition, Premier League BiH "(Premijer Liga)", happened in the fall 2000. However, the first <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">2000–01</a> season seen clubs from <a href="Federation%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Federation of BiH</a> only, while clubs from Republic of Srpska entity continue to compete in their own separate league as their entity association still refused to join agreed unified N/FSBiH and its new competition. However, UEFA and FIFA never intended to recognize this separate organization nor its competition, which meant clubs could not compete outside territory of the entity and would not compete internationally. This situation forced clubs to insist that their organization also join N/FSBiH, and two years later they became part of the competition for the season <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">2002–03</a>. Ever since the year 2000 Premier League is the top tier of Bosnia and Herzegovina football, with two entity-based leagues, First League of Republika Srpska and First League of the Federation of BiH, being pushed to the second tier of the football pyramid and serve as feeder leagues to Premier League.
Premier League as Liga 12 from 2016–17 until 2018–19.
During the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">2016–17 season</a> and the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">2017–18 season</a> BH Telecom Premier League had changed its format entirely, reducing a number of clubs from 16 to 12, thus sometimes referred to as "Liga 12" (League 12), with the calendar also modified accordingly, and introducing <a href="playoffs">playoffs</a> (also known as the "title playoffs") and play out.
Number of matches were played by each club during regular season after which, according to their position, they entered to play-offs or play out. Playoffs were contested by the top 6 clubs in the regular season, with each club playing each other twice for the title, which guarantees <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> qualifications, second and third place, guaranteeing <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">Europa League</a> qualifications berths. Play out was contested by six clubs to avoid relegation with last two teams being relegated.
Old format since 2018–19.
Since the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">2018–19 season</a>, the league is not played as the last two seasons before. Actually very simple, after all the 12 clubs play each other two times, once home and once away, they play each other three times, also playing home or away depending on how the schedule is made. With that, the league season has 33 full rounds instead of the 22 rounds and an additional 10 rounds in the relegation and championship games.
Sponsorship.
On 31 July 2012, the <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Football Association of Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> signed a two-year deal with <a href="BH%20Telecom">BH Telecom</a> regarding the sponsorship of the league, effectively renaming the league BH Telecom Premier League. The deal was extended once more before the start of 2014–15 season. On 24 July 2020, it was announced that <a href="Mtel%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Mtel</a> had become the new league sponsor for the next three years with an estimate 23 Million <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20convertible%20mark">BAM</a> worth, renaming the league m:tel Premier League.

Premier League Champions.
Since <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">2000–01 season</a> the first tier of Bosnia and Herzegovina football competition became "Premier League of Bosnia and Herzegovina".
1 Played without clubs from the Republika Srpska entity of BiH which have only taken part in the league since 2002.
Times finished in first three.

The following table lists the champions by cities; Counting since when the Premier League of Bosnia and Herzegovina is played and recognized by UEFA, season <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">2000–01</a>
Notable performances in Europe.
In the qualifiers for the UEFA Champions League season <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2002–03</a>, <a href="FK%20%C5%BDeljezni%C4%8Dar%20Sarajevo">Željezničar</a> gained the greatest success in Bosnian post-war club-football so far, going all the way to the last qualifying round for the most important club competition in Europe. After big wins over <a href="%C3%8D%C3%BEr%C3%B3ttabandalag%20Akraness">ÍA Akraness</a> and <a href="Lillestr%C3%B8m%20SK">Lillestrøm</a>, however, they were held by <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a>. In the first match, held in Sarajevo, Newcastle won 0–1 with English team defeating Željezničar 4–0 in England.
The second time a Bosnian club moved into the last qualifying round of the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> was <a href="FK%20Sarajevo">FK Sarajevo</a> in <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2007–08</a>, when they lost to <a href="FC%20Dynamo%20Kyiv">Dynamo Kyiv</a> 0–4 on aggregate, after going over Maltese <a href="Marsaxlokk%20F.C.">Marsaxlokk</a> and Belgian side <a href="K.R.C.%20Genk">Genk</a>.
Another remarkable season for Bosnian clubs in Europe was 2009–10. The most memorable performances were marked by <a href="FK%20Sarajevo">FK Sarajevo</a> and <a href="FK%20Slavija%20Sarajevo">Slavija</a>. While Slavija surprisingly beat <a href="AaB%20Fodbold">Aalborg</a> in the Second Qualifying round but could not overcome <a href="FC%20VSS%20Ko%C5%A1ice">MFK Košice</a> in the third round, <a href="FK%20Sarajevo">FK Sarajevo</a> was able to reach the <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20qualifying%20phase%20and%20play-off%20round">Play-offs</a> for the Group Stage of the newly formed <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Europa League</a> after beating <a href="FC%20Spartak%20Trnava">Spartak Trnava</a> and <a href="Helsingborgs%20IF">Helsingborg</a>. However, they lost there unhappily 3–2 on aggregate to <a href="CFR%20Cluj">CFR Cluj</a>. FK Sarajevo made it again in <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20qualifying%20phase%20and%20play-off%20round%23Matches%203">2014–15</a> <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Europa League</a> playing all the way to the play-off round where they lost to <a href="Borussia%20M%C3%B6nchengladbach">Borussia Mönchengladbach</a>. In the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2020–21 UEFA Europa League</a> season, Sarajevo once again played in the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%23Play-off%20round">play-off round</a>, this time losing to <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a>.
